content.text: Node.js and Raspberry Pi
Raspberry Pi is a small, multi-use computer.
content.html: Raspberry Pi is a small, multi-use computer.

content.text: With Node.js you can do amazing things with your Raspberry Pi.
content.html: With Node.js you can do amazing things with your Raspberry Pi.

content.text: What is the Raspberry Pi?
The Raspberry Pi is a small, affordable, and amazingly capable, credit card size computer.
content.html: The Raspberry Pi is a small, affordable, and amazingly capable, credit card size computer.

content.text: It is developed by the Raspberry Pi Foundation, and it might be the most versatile tech ever created.
content.html: It is developed by the Raspberry Pi Foundation, and it might be the most versatile tech ever created.

content.text: Creator Eben Upton's goal was to create a low-cost device that would improve programming skills and hardware understanding.
content.html: Creator Eben Upton's goal was to create a low-cost device that would improve programming skills and hardware understanding.

content.text: Due to the small size and price of the device, it has become the center of a wide range of projects by tinkerers, makers, and electronics enthusiasts.
content.html: Due to the small size and price of the device, it has become the center of a wide range of projects by tinkerers, makers, and electronics enthusiasts.

content.text: Raspberry Pi and Node.js

The Raspberry Pi has a row of GPIO (General Purpose input/output) pins, and these can be used to interact in amazing ways with the real world. This tutorial will focus on how to use these with Node.js.
content.html: The Raspberry Pi has a row of GPIO (General Purpose input/output) pins, and these can be used to interact in amazing ways with the real world. This tutorial will focus on how to use these with Node.js.

content.text: What Do I Need?
For this tutorial you need a Raspberry Pi. In our examples we use a Raspberry Pi 3, but this tutorial should work for most versions.
content.html: For this tutorial you need a Raspberry Pi. In our examples we use a Raspberry Pi 3, but this tutorial should work for most versions.

content.text: Hardware needed:
content.html: Hardware needed:

content.text: For later chapters in this tutorial we will use special sensors or devices that we connect to the Raspberry Pi. We will specify these as special requirements in the relevant chapters.
content.html: For later chapters in this tutorial we will use special sensors or devices that we connect to the Raspberry Pi. We will specify these as special requirements in the relevant chapters.

content.text: If you already have a Raspberry Pi set up with Raspbian, internet and enabled SSH, you can skip to the step "Install Node.js on Raspberry Pi".
content.html: If you already have a Raspberry Pi set up with Raspbian, internet and enabled SSH, you can skip to the step "Install Node.js on Raspberry Pi".

content.text: Write Raspbian OS Image to MicroSD Card
Before we can start using our Raspberry Pi for anything, we need to get a OS installed.
content.html: Before we can start using our Raspberry Pi for anything, we need to get a OS installed.

content.text: Raspbian is a free operating system based on Debian Linux, and it is optimized Raspberry Pi.
content.html: Raspbian is a free operating system based on Debian Linux, and it is optimized Raspberry Pi.

content.text: Download the latest Raspbian image from https://www.raspberrypi.org/downloads/raspbian/ to your computer.
content.html: Download the latest Raspbian image from https://www.raspberrypi.org/downloads/raspbian/ to your computer.

content.text: We use the "LITE" version in our tutorial, since we are setting the Raspberry Pi up as a headless server (we will connect to it through SSH, without having a keyboard/display connected to it). You can use whichever version you want, but this tutorial is written with the "LITE" version as its focus.
content.html: We use the "LITE" version in our tutorial, since we are setting the Raspberry Pi up as a headless server (we will connect to it through SSH, without having a keyboard/display connected to it). You can use whichever version you want, but this tutorial is written with the "LITE" version as its focus.

content.text: Insert the MicroSD memory card in your computer (via the SD adapter if needed). Open File Explorer to verify that it is operational.
content.html: Insert the MicroSD memory card in your computer (via the SD adapter if needed). Open File Explorer to verify that it is operational.

content.text: Etcher is a program for flashing images to memory cards. Download and install Etcher from: https://etcher.io/
content.html: Etcher is a program for flashing images to memory cards. Download and install Etcher from: https://etcher.io/

content.text: Launch Etcher:
content.html: Launch Etcher:

content.text: Click "Select image" button and find the Raspbian zip file that you downloaded.
content.html: Click "Select image" button and find the Raspbian zip file that you downloaded.

content.text: Click the "Select drive" button and specify the memory card as the target location.
content.html: Click the "Select drive" button and specify the memory card as the target location.

content.text: Click the "Flash!" button to write the image to the memory card.
content.html: Click the "Flash!" button to write the image to the memory card.

content.text: After Etcher is finished writing the image to the memory card, remove it from your computer.
content.html: After Etcher is finished writing the image to the memory card, remove it from your computer.

content.text: Set up Your Raspberry Pi
To get the Raspberry Pi ready to boot we need to:
content.html: To get the Raspberry Pi ready to boot we need to:

content.text: When the Raspberry Pi is finished booting up, log in using username: pi and password: raspberry
content.html: When the Raspberry Pi is finished booting up, log in using username: pi and password: raspberry

content.text: Set Up Network on the Raspberry Pi
If you will use a Ethernet cable to connect your Raspberry Pi to the internet, you can skip this step.
content.html: If you will use a Ethernet cable to connect your Raspberry Pi to the internet, you can skip this step.

content.text: For this section we will assume you have a Raspberry Pi 3, with built in WiFi.
content.html: For this section we will assume you have a Raspberry Pi 3, with built in WiFi.

content.text: Start by scanning for wireless networks:
content.html: Start by scanning for wireless networks:

content.code_html: pi@raspberrypi:~ $ sudo iwlist wlan0 scan

content.text: This will list all of the available WiFi networks. (It also confirms that your WiFi is working)
content.html: This will list all of the available WiFi networks. (It also confirms that your WiFi is working)

content.text: Now we need to open the wpa-supplicant file, to add the network you want to connect to:
content.html: Now we need to open the wpa-supplicant file, to add the network you want to connect to:

content.code_html: pi@raspberrypi:~ $ sudo nano /etc/wpa_supplicant/wpa_supplicant.conf

content.text: This will open the file in the Nano editor. Add the following to the bottom of the file (change wifiName and wifiPassword with the actual network name and password):
content.html: This will open the file in the Nano editor. Add the following to the bottom of the file (change wifiName and wifiPassword with the actual network name and password):

content.code_html:
network={
  ssid="wifiName"
  psk="wifiPassword"
}

content.text: Press " Ctrl+x " to save the code. Confirm with " y ", and confirm the name with " Enter ".
content.html: Press "Ctrl+x" to save the code. Confirm with "y", and confirm the name with "Enter".

content.text: And reboot the Raspberry Pi:
content.html: And reboot the Raspberry Pi:

content.code_html: pi@raspberrypi:~ $ sudo reboot

content.text: After reboot, log in again, and confirm that the WiFi is connected and working:
content.html: After reboot, log in again, and confirm that the WiFi is connected and working:

content.code_html: pi@raspberrypi:~ $ ifconfig wlan0

content.text: If the WiFi is working propery, the information displayed should include an IP address, similar to this:
content.html: If the WiFi is working propery, the information displayed should include an IP address, similar to this:

content.text: Write down that IP address, as we will use it to connect to the Raspberry Pi via SSH.
content.html: Write down that IP address, as we will use it to connect to the Raspberry Pi via SSH.

content.text: Enable SSH, Change Hostname and Password
Now your Raspberry Pi is connected to the internet, it is time to enable SSH.
content.html: Now your Raspberry Pi is connected to the internet, it is time to enable SSH.

content.text: SSH allows you up use the Raspberry Pi without having a monitor and keyboard connected to it.
content.html: SSH allows you up use the Raspberry Pi without having a monitor and keyboard connected to it.

content.text: (You will need a SSH client for this on your non-Raspberry Pi computer. We use PuTTY for windows)
content.html: (You will need a SSH client for this on your non-Raspberry Pi computer. We use PuTTY for windows)

content.text: Open the Raspberry Pi Software Configuration Tool:
content.html: Open the Raspberry Pi Software Configuration Tool:

content.code_html: pi@raspberrypi:~ $ sudo raspi-config

content.text: You should see a menu like this:
content.html: You should see a menu like this:

content.text: Select option 5 Interfacing Options :
content.html: Select option 5 Interfacing Options:

content.text: Select option P2 SSH , to activate SSH:
content.html: Select option P2 SSH, to activate SSH:

content.text: Confirm with YES , to activate SSH:
content.html: Confirm with YES, to activate SSH:

content.text: SSH is now enabled, and you should be in the main menu again.
content.html: SSH is now enabled, and you should be in the main menu again.

content.text: Select 1 Change User Password , and follow the instructions to change the password. Choose a secure password, but something you will remember:
content.html: Select 1 Change User Password, and follow the instructions to change the password. Choose a secure password, but something you will remember:

content.text: After you have finished changing the password, you should be back in the main menu.
content.html: After you have finished changing the password, you should be back in the main menu.

content.text: Select 2 Hostname , and follow the instructions to change the hostname:
content.html: Select 2 Hostname, and follow the instructions to change the hostname:

content.text: After you have finished changing the hostname, you should be back in the main menu.
content.html: After you have finished changing the hostname, you should be back in the main menu.

content.text: Now we will close the menu and save the changes:
content.html: Now we will close the menu and save the changes:

content.text: When selecting Finish , you will get the option to reboot. Select Yes to reboot the Raspberry Pi.
content.html: When selecting Finish, you will get the option to reboot. Select Yes to reboot the Raspberry Pi.

content.text: You can now unplug the monitor and keyboard from the Raspberry Pi, and we can log in using out SSH client.
content.html: You can now unplug the monitor and keyboard from the Raspberry Pi, and we can log in using out SSH client.

content.text: Open PuTTY, type in the IP address for your Raspberry Pi, and click Open :
content.html: Open PuTTY, type in the IP address for your Raspberry Pi, and click Open:

content.text: Log in using the username pi and the new password you specified.
content.html: Log in using the username pi and the new password you specified.

content.text: You should now see a command line like this: (we used w3demopi as our hostname)
content.html: You should now see a command line like this: (we used w3demopi as our hostname)

content.text: You are now able to run your Raspberry Pi in "Headless-mode", meaning you do not need a monitor or keyboard. And if you have a WiFi connection, you do not need a ethernet cable either, just the power cable!
content.html: You are now able to run your Raspberry Pi in "Headless-mode", meaning you do not need a monitor or keyboard. And if you have a WiFi connection, you do not need a ethernet cable either, just the power cable!

content.text: Install Node.js on Raspberry Pi
With the Raspberry Pi properly set up, login in via SSH, and update your Raspberry Pi system packages to their latest versions.
content.html: With the Raspberry Pi properly set up, login in via SSH, and update your Raspberry Pi system packages to their latest versions.

content.text: Update your system package list:
content.html: Update your system package list:

content.code_html: pi@w3demopi:~ $ sudo apt-get update

content.text: Upgrade all your installed packages to their latest version:
content.html: Upgrade all your installed packages to their latest version:

content.code_html: pi@w3demopi:~ $ sudo apt-get dist-upgrade

content.text: Doing this regularly will keep your Raspberry Pi installation up to date.
content.html: Doing this regularly will keep your Raspberry Pi installation up to date.

content.text: To download and install newest version of Node.js, use the following command:
content.html: To download and install newest version of Node.js, use the following command:

content.code_html: pi@w3demopi:~ $ curl -sL https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_8.x | sudo -E bash -

content.text: Now install it by running:
content.html: Now install it by running:

content.code_html: pi@w3demopi:~ $ sudo apt-get install -y nodejs

content.text: Check that the installation was successful, and the version number of Node.js with:
content.html: Check that the installation was successful, and the version number of Node.js with:

Now you have a Raspberry Pi with Node.js installed!
content.html: Now you have a Raspberry Pi with Node.js installed!

content.html: If you want to learn more about Node.js, follow our tutorial: https://www.w3schools.com/nodejs/
